PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Douglas McClelland) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

PETITION.TITLE: Retirement Income Policy
PETITION.PARA: The Clerk-Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:
Retirement Income Policy
To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled: The petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth that:
1. the Hawke Labor Government's retirement income policies are piecemeal, inconsistent and make no provision to encourage people to save towards their retirements; and,
2. the Government's proposed assets test legislation is iniquitous and, if enacted, its effects would be discriminatory.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to:
1. scrap its proposed assets test legislation;
2. either institute a broad enquiry into Australia's retirement income and taxation systems or await the outcome of the Senate Standing Committee on Social Welfare's work on this matter; and,
3. following the report of such a wide enquiry institute a retirement income policy which is fair and equitable, that encourages self-provision and which will be non-discriminatory.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Customs Regulations: Importation of Video Material
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth:

That Regulations and an Ordinance before the Parliament amend the Customs ( Prohibited Imports) Regulation and the Customs (Cinematograph and Films) Regulations and supersedes the ACT Objectionable Publications Ordinance in such a manner as to be harmful to society by removing from existing Commonwealth Law-
The power to prevent the importation and sale of hard core pornography (e.g. X- rated videos) and publications which consistently incite the use of hard drugs;
The power to prevent the importation and sale of grossly obscene publications including those associated with blasphemy;
The power to require videos for non-commercial use to be registered by the Films Censorship Board before release from Customs.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should disallow the new Regulations and Ordinance and ensure:
That the Attorney-General enforce existing laws;
That the Censors more appropriately reflect reasonable and responsible community attitudes;
That further measures be taken in association with the States to protect Australians, particularly women and children, from exploitation;
That, because of the importance of this issue to the whole community a conscience vote be permitted to all Members of Parliament.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Scott (from nine citizens), Walters (from 114 citizens) and Watson ( from 54 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Funding for Technical and Further Education Colleges
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned teachers and students working and studying in TAFE colleges throughout Australia respectfully showeth that:
1. We assert that TAFE, with over 1 million students, requires greatly improved resources if it is to continue to train Australia's skilled workforce effectively.

2. We call upon the Commonwealth Government to provide greatly increased funds to ensure that TAFE is accessible to all Australians, unlike the present time when thousands of people are turned away from TAFE colleges each year.

3. We urge the Commonwealth Government to equip TAFE workshops with the advanced technology used in modern Australian industries, and to expand TAFE's capital works program so that sufficient quality accommodation is available for TAFE teachers and students.
4. We ask that the Commonwealth Government greatly increase TAFE's recurrent expenditure, so that TAFE can respond quickly and flexibly to industry, Government and community demands.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Tertiary Student Residential College Accommodation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled: This petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that the reduction in the subsidy to tertiary student residential colleges of twenty-five per cent announced in the Federal Budget will:

1. Increase the financial hardship already being experienced by Australian students. The cut in subsidies to colleges will undoubtedly increase fees for that accommodation in 1984. Many students will be forced out of tertiary education as they will not be able to meet these increased costs particularly as the Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme only gained a maximum increase of $2.80 per week in the Federal Budget.

2. Decrease access to education for country students. Many country students live in college accommodation either to attend tertiary institutions in the metropolitan area or in regional centres. The cut in the subsidy to residential colleges will even further disadvantage this group of students who already have comparatively low participation rates in tertiary education.
Your petitioners therefore call upon the Senate to ensure:
(1) That the full subsidy to student college accommodation is immediately restored.
(2) That the Federal Government assume financial responsibility for all student college accommodation to prevent the planned closures of colleges in Victoria.
(3) That two student representatives are appointed to the committee of the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission reviewing student housing.

(4) That new forms of college accommodation are investigated which would be more appropriate to the needs of the current student population, i.e. accommodation appropriate for students with dependent children.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Haines)-agreed to:
That leave be given to introduce a Bill for an Act to protect private property from unjust acquisition under certain laws.
Bill presented, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: — by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to incorporate my second reading speech in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

In a democracy people have a right to expect that their property will not be compulsorily acquired without adequate compensation. The emergence of the modern , parliamentary democratic system was closely aligned with the development of a legal code that protected an individual's property. Arbitrary confiscation of property was a characteristic of despotic regimes which parliamentary democracy ought not to countenance. The purpose of this Bill is to protect private property from such unjust acquisition.

The Westminster system of democracy, the British legal system and the social philosophy of liberalism all recognise the connection between the liberty of the individual and the individual's right to property.

The first modern democrats concerned with the protection of the rights of a person against the tyranny of an individual or a group of individuals, recognised that the inherent capacity of a tyrant to deprive an individual of property also represented the ability of the State to deprive the individual of liberty.

Of course times have changed. Modern democracies recognise that property ownership confers social responsibilities and therefore that the State has a reasonable right to direct the way in which property is used and disposed of. The individual's right to property therefore may need to be tempered by government action that enforces this social responsibility if such action is for the good of society.

I believe a government has the right to make demands with regard to the use and disposal of property. Each case must be judged individually, but governments ought not to be precluded from taking action on behalf of the community.

However when a government seeks to conflict with an individual's right to use and dispose of property, the proper course in a democracy is not to confiscate but to compensate. History abounds with examples of non-democratically elected leaders confiscating property from particular groups, e.g. ethnic or religious, without just compensation. They confiscated property in the name of the State, and for the ''good'' of the community, but were not interested in giving their victims just compensation. In so doing, they attacked the liberty of individuals , depriving them of their property and ultimately their livelihood. In fact, the modern form of despotism is even more vicious than its 17th, 18th and 19th century predecessors, and like them it has no regard for property rights and therefore individual rights.

In this historical context, the choice for Australia is clear: in dealing with property rights we can continue to follow in the liberal democratic model which has a high regard for an individual's property or we can follow the totalitarian model which deprives the individual of all rights and therefore does not respect the right of an individual to own property.

Recent events in New South Wales, following the enactment of the Wran Government's Coal Acquisition Act of 1981 are a case in point. In a simple and savage move, that Government declared that the historical rights of thousands of New South Wales freehold landowners to whatever coal might be found on or under their property, no longer existed. In a manner somewhat reminiscent of Stalin, Mr Wran claimed the coal was now the 'people's coal'.

I am not going to dwell on Mr Wran's motives for taking such action. I am more concerned with the fact that to date, no compensation has been paid, and that the New South Wales Government shows no inclination to make just compensation to those who were deprived of their property as a result of the legislation that Government enacted.
Mr Wran has clearly chosen the path of the tyrant in deciding on what terms to acquire property.

Until recently this action had aroused little public interest or outcry. The reason for this may have been that coal owners are believed to be a comparatively small group of people, most of whom are thought to be wealthy. In fact, this is not the case and the Freehold Rights Association has estimated that of the 10,000 or so people involved, about a quarter are pensioners.

In any case, the wealth of the people involved is not really at issue. I would hope that in a democratic society the property rights of all individuals would be respected, irrespective of whether the Government deems them to be well-off or not.

The Constitution of the Commonwealth of Australia (section 51, paragraph xxxi) ensures that no law of the Commonwealth can cause the property of a person to be acquired otherwise than on just terms. However, the Constitutions of the Australian States do not necessarily make such a provision. I believe it is rather ironic that, while the Commonwealth Government would be restrained by the Constitution from acting in the despotic manner of the Wran Government, New South Wales and other State governments can apparently do so with impunity.

The Universal Declaration of Human Rights adopted by the General Assembly of the United Nations in 1948, provides in Article 17 that everyone has the right to own property and no-one shall be arbitrarily deprived of property. Futhermore , the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, to which Australia is a party and which entered into force for Australia on November 13, 1980, provides in Article 26, that all persons are equal before the law and are entitled without discrimination to the equal protection of the law. That law prohibits any discrimination and guarantees to all persons equal and effective protection against discrimination on any grounds including property.
Australia, as a party to that Covenant, under Article 2, undertakes to ensure that any person whose rights or freedoms as recognised by the Convention are violated shall have effective remedy.

Acquisitions directly under Commonwealth Acts are not covered by the Bill because as mentioned in the preamble, the Constitution already requires such acquisitions to be on just terms (except in the Territories). Futhermore, the Parliament could not bind itself as to its own future Acts.

The High Court held, in the case of Teori Tau v. the Commonwealth (1969) 119CLR 564, that the just terms requirement of the Constitution does not apply to acquisitions in a Territory. The Bill, therefore, extends to acquisitions by subordinate legislatures for the Territories (including the Governor-General in Council).

As to the definition of 'prescribed day' in clause 5, the Covenant was ratified by Australia in 1980, with the date of deposit of the instrument of ratification being 13 August 1980. Under Article 49 of the Covenant, the Covenant entered into force for Australia three months later, on 13 November 1980.

The effect of clause 6 would be that any future purported unjust acquisition by State law would be to no effect. The property would not be divested from its owner and no compensation would therefore be necessary. However, clause 7 deals with acquisitions that may have taken place between the prescribed date and the commencement of the Act, such as acquisitions under the Coal Acquisition Act, 1981 of New South Wales. Those acquisitions have been legally effective. The Bill does not propose to re-vest the property in the former owners but proposes to give an enforceable right to just compensation. Sub-clause (2) makes it quite explicit that the clause applies in relation to the Coal Acquisition Act, 1981 of New South Wales.

This Bill will give people whose property rights have been infringed by a State government the right to an effective remedy. It simply requires that acquisition be on just terms or else the purported acquisition will have no effect. It will, therefore, protect the individual from an excessive and tyrannical abuse of the power of a State government. It will ensure that people are not left to the mercy of a greedy State government which chooses to acquire property in the manner of a totalitarian regime, rather than in the tradition of a parliamentary democratic system which respects the rights of individuals in particular their right to adequate compensation following compulsory property acquisition.
Debate (on motion by Senator Robertson) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: LOAN (INCOME EQUALIZATION DEPOSITS) AMENDMENT BILL 1984INCOME TAX ASSESSMENT AMENDMENT (INCOME EQUALIZATION DEPOSITS) BILL 1984

Ordered that the Bills may be taken through all their stages without delay.
Bills (on motion by Senator Grimes) read a first time.
Second Readings

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bills be now read a second time.
I seek leave to incorporate the second reading speeches in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speeches read as follows-
LOAN (INCOME EQUALIZATION DEPOSITS) AMENDMENT BILL 1984

The purpose of this Bill is to give legislative effect to changes to the income equalization deposits scheme, first announced in the Treasurer's economic statement to the Parliament of 19 May, 1983. Further ministerial announcements on 16 June, 1983 and on 23 August, 1983 expanded upon the proposed nature of those changes.

The Income Equalization Deposits Scheme, as amended, will have no taxation consequences other than the taxation of interest as income. The Government decided to remove the scheme from the tax system to prevent the possibility of its use for tax avoidance and so as to make the benefits accruing from the scheme more evenly available to all primary producers. The old arrangements had a degree of inequity, in that producers on the highest marginal tax rate, that is, on the highest incomes, benefitted most.

As the provisions of the new scheme have been well publicized already, and as the details of the Loan (Income Equalization Deposits) Amendment Bill 1984 are explained in detail in a memorandum which I have arranged to be circulated, I shall confine my comments to outlining the broad features of the amended scheme.
The aim of the scheme is to encourage primary producers to deposit moneys, in years when their incomes are high, so as to provide funds which can be drawn when incomes are lower.
The incentive to make such deposits is an attractive interest rate, set quarterly at two percentage points above the short term Commonwealth Treasury Bond rate.
The eligibility criteria which determine whether this high rate is received on deposits will be broadly the same as under former arrangements.
All primary producers, but only primary producers, are eligible for the higher rate.
Deposits can be made up to a limit of a $250,000 deposit stock. Above that, they will not be eligible for the higher rate.
In respect of any income year a primary producer may make new deposits which receive the higher rate of interest, up to an amount equivalent to the lesser of :
sixty per cent of gross receipts from primary production in respect of that year; and
taxable income, other than income derived from property, in respect of that year.

A deposit made at the higher rate will continue to receive that rate subject to the Taxation Commissioner's confirmation of eligibility estimates and as long as the depositor continues in the business of primary production.

The determination of eligibility will be a two step procedure. The first step will be taken by the primary producer, self estimating the eligible deposit level for his or her current income year. This allows primary producers to take advantage of a current high income year to make deposits at the attractive interest rates.

Interest payments in respect of new deposits will be based essentially on this self-estimation process. Provision is also being made, however, for the Commissioner of Taxation to provide an accurate assessment of the income of depositors and to provide that assessment to the Administrator of the scheme, who is to be known as the authorized person. The authorized person will only need to make an adjustment to the interest entitlement of the depositor if the commissioner's assessment effectively lowers the depositors' eligibility for interest payments at the high interest rate below the level which would otherwise be payable in respect of deposits actually made. Provision is being included to recoup any overpayments of interest which arise from overestimation by the depositor. Unwitting overestimation of income and deposit amounts will not be penalized, other than by recoupment. Furthermore, deposits made as a result of overestimates by primary producers will be able to be withdrawn without penalty immediately the Commissioner of Taxation's Determination is known.
However, overestimation and deposit with intent to defraud is an offence under the Bill.

The Bill provides for primary producer depositors to retain their ongoing entitlement to the high interest rate if they move in and out of primary production, or change primary production endeavours so long as they are not absent from primary production for a period exceeding 120 days. Of course new deposits may be made after resumption of primary production beyond that period and they would receive the higher interest rate if the eligibility criteria were then satisfied.
The Amendment Bill provides that a depositor is required to notify the authorized person of the cessation of primary production business.

Withdrawals from the scheme will be possible on a similar basis as in the past. That is, deposits may be withdrawn at any time after 12 months, or within that time on grounds of financial hardship. Hardship will initially be judged by the authorised person. If the depositor who is claiming hardship is dissatisfied with the initial judgement, he or she may approach the Administrative Appeals Tribunal for a ruling.

The impact of the new arrangements on the future levels of deposits and withdrawals is very difficult to project with any degree of accuracy. Deposits have been continuing to ease since 1982. There may have been some natural pause in deposit intake toward the end of, and immediately following, the drought and also during the period of transition between the new scheme coming into effect on 1 September, 1983 and the application of this amending legislation. It will be necessary to observe the deposit performance over some period before accurate projections can be made about the longer term trend of deposits.

The level of interest payments will depend on the level of deposits and so they are also very difficult to project accurately. The interest rates applying to the new scheme have been higher than those offered under former arrangements. However unrecouped income tax deductions will be brought to account at the time of conversions and this will offset the cost of the Budget of the higher interest rate.
Furthermore, the new scheme has none of the characteristics which enabled depositors to avoid tax under former arrangements.
The difference in administrative cost caused by the changed arrangements is expected to be small.

The new IED scheme has been designed to allow primary producers to deposit funds with the Commonwealth at interest rates higher, and conditions more favourable, than those on Commonwealth Securities offered to the general public.

This subsidy is intended to motivate primary producers to prepare for lean years but does not enable the wealthy to benefit more per dollar deposited, as did the former scheme. As such, this scheme should be particularly welcomed by smaller primary producers and those concerned with equity in our community.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
INCOME TAX ASSESSMENT AMENDMENT (INCOME EQUALISATION DEPOSITS) BILL 1984
This Bill is complementary to the Loan (Income Equalization Deposits) Amendment Bill 1984 which I have just introduced.
In introducing that Bill I outlined the features of the new Income Equalization Deposits Scheme which has been developed by the Government and which will operate with effect from 1 September 1983.
The new arrangements are far more equitable than the ones they replace and will better serve to encourage primary producers to make due provision for adverse seasons.
The provisions of this Bill are consequential upon amendments of the Loan ( Income Equalization Deposits) Act 1976 proposed by the earlier Bill.

Their main purpose is to amend the income tax law to make changes to the taxation treatment of income equalization deposits in harmony with the decision to replace the former tax incentive basis of the scheme with one based on the payment of attractive interest rates on deposits.
Accordingly, deposits made after 1 September 1983 will carry no special tax consequences.
In particular, the income tax deduction previously allowable for eligible deposits made within specified limits is to be terminated.

In outlining the provisions of the earlier Bill, I made it clear that, under the new arrangements, drought bonds and deposits made before 1 September 1983 may be transferred to the new scheme to enable depositors to take advantage of the special rate of interest payable under that scheme.

Consistently with the basis on which income tax deductions were allowed under the former arrangements, where drought bonds or pre-1 September 1983 deposits are converted to the new scheme the amount so converted will be included in the depositor's assessable income of the year of income in which the conversion takes place.
Depositors who apply to convert to the new arrangements within 60 days after the Bill receives Royal Assent will, for these purposes, be taken to have done so on 1 September 1983.
Of course, no amount will be required to be included in assessable income in respect of drought bonds or income equalization deposits that did not qualify for deduction.

The Bill will also permit the Commissioner of Taxation and his officers to furnish relevant information contained in tax returns to authorized persons involved in the administration of the new IED scheme.
This is necessary because eligibility criteria applying to depositors under the new scheme will continue to be based on tax-related factors.
A technical explanation of the Bill is contained in the explanatory memorandum that is being made available to honourable senators.
I commend this Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Chaney) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Ordered that the Bill may be taken through all its stages without delay.
Bill (on motion by Senator Grimes) read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

The Patents Amendment Bill 1984 does not make any dramatic policy changes. It does however reflect dramatic changes in technology which are taking place in the world. Those changes will continue whether or not Australian industy meets the challenges to take part in them. The role of Government in meeting the challenge includes assisting industry to identify areas in which Australians can participate effectively and fruitfully. The crisis confronting Australian industry is that we are falling behind the rest of the world. To keep up we must concentrate on areas in which Australia can generate new technologies and take a fair share of tomorrow's prosperity. One such area already identified is biotechnology. The purpose of the Patents Amendment Bill is to encourage commercial realisation of biotechnology research in Australia. The Bill also makes possible Australia's accession to the Budapest Treaty on the International Recognition of the Deposit of Micro-organisms for the purposes of Patent Procedure. These measures complement a program of Government support for biotechnology including a Budget allocation for 1983/84 of $12.2 million.
Good research, but where is the development

Australia was once content to ride on the sheep's back, but the time came when the sheep was no longer moving fast enough to keep up with the rest of the world . The wool market was not enough to ensure national prosperity, so we eventually took an interest in manufacturing and mining. Now some of us are clinging to a new sheep's back in the form of out-dated technology.

With its 15 million people, Australia has 0.3% of the world's population. We perform 2.0% of the world's scientific research, but originate 0.7% of patents and undertake only 0.1% of high technology production. Australia is in the middle rank of OECD nations in terms of government expenditure on research and development. But because of the very small contribution by industry we fall near the bottom of the list in terms of gross expenditure on research and development .
Of the total of $1,054 million spent on GERD in Australia during 1978-79, government sources funded 4/5. Business enterprise sources were responsible for only 1/5 of the funds.
The poor performance of the Australian private sector in R&D finds its reflection in Australia's comparative standing as a technologically-advanced country.

The Australian Bureau of Statistics collects information relating to receipts and payments, by business, for technical know-how. Figures for 1981-82 show that , uncorrected for inflation, both payments and receipts decreased in the period from 1978-79 to 1981-82, payments by 8% and receipts by 7%. By comparison with other OECD countries, Australia's level of both import and export is very low. It may come as no surprise that the Netherlands had receipts for technical know- how of the order of twenty times as great as ours, in 1978; but payments also, were much higher-three times our level.

On an expenditure basis, Australia performs about 0.9% of the world's applied research and experimental development other than that performed by the US, and over the period 1963-1979 obtained 0.9% of the foreign patents awarded in the US . Nevertheless, on a per capita basis Australia was strongly outperformed in US patents by the small developed European nations, specially Switzerland, Sweden, Netherlands. Belgium, Austria and Denmark.

The Science and Technology Statement for 1982-83 presents the results of a collation of statistics relating to the import and export of goods with a high research component. This collation shows that in 1980 Australia exported US$681 per capita of such goods, which makes for a startling comparison with Switzerland, for which the figure is $2,584, Netherlands (1,378), Belgium (1,352 ), Sweden (1,087), Denmark (882), Austria (720), Ireland (589), Finland (509) and Norway (507). The figure taken over all OECD countries is US$468 per capita, with Portugal, Greece and Turkey having lower figures than Australia.

In 1980-81 Australia ran a trade deficit of some $A6 billion in goods with a high research component. The deficit for all manufacturers was about $10 billion ; overall there was a trade balance, with imports and exports each totalling about $19 billion. A deficit in goods having a significant research component has been a normal part of Australia's trade pattern, but in the last decade it has increased rapidly.

Thus we find ourselves in Australia doing a great deal of pure research but not making much commercial or economic gain from it. Government funded pure research largely passes into the public domain and Australian industry clings to the technological sheep's back of the 1950's and 60's.
Biotechnology

Radical change is needed to correct this imbalance. Australia must make a transition towards newly developing high-technology ''sunrise'' industries as wealth generators for our future, in addition to restructuring and revitalising our existing industrial base. Of these sunrise industries, biotechnology holds the greatest promise. It is sparing and efficient in its use of resources, and has almost unbounded applications in many areas of technology.

There is nothing new or frightening in basing economic activities on the useful properties of living things. Agriculture has always been so based. Micro- organisms have been used for millennia to make cheese, wine, beer and bread. Industrial fermentations to produce antibiotics, citric acid and ethanol have been used for decades. This is not to mention that amazingly adaptable bacterium , E. coli, now famous in biotechnology, which has been serving the alimentary needs of the human species through the entire peristaltic course of history. Modern biotechnology expands and refines the use of living organisms into new and marvellously exciting areas of activity. Human insulin produced by genetically modified micro-organisms is now on the market.

Most important for Australia, we have biotechnology researchers who are world leaders in agriculture, plant and animal genetics, microbiology, biochemistry and medical research. We must take advantage of the leads we have. A symposium and a workshop arranged through my Department have identified the following priority areas:
plant agriculture, including genetic engineering to modify microbes, and tissue culture to improve plant species
veterinary research, particularly on diagnostic probes and vaccines
animal husbandry, including advanced breeding techniques and work on animal hormones
human pharmaceutical and medical research, particularly on hormones, immunoproteins, and diagnostic probes
biotechnology support, including equipment, instrumentation, and resources and processes
food processing, in cheesemaking and other dairy production, and baking and brewing
chemical industry, particularly water treatment.
This list is only indicative and there will be worthwhile programs in other areas.
Government support for biotechnology development

These priority areas have been incorporated into the criteria for the National Biotechnology Program established by the Government in 1983. We aim in the national interest to broaden and strengthen the slender and rickety bridge between academic researchers and industry. Closer co-operation will help to make our best research findings available to commercially oriented and competitive industry.

Research grants totalling $4.51 million which were announced in December last year are the first given under the Program. They span the years 1984 to 1986, and include $1.5 million in 1983-84. Most of the seven projects involve special collaboration between researchers and industry. Research institutions include the Walter and Eliza Hall Institute, Queensland Institute of Medical Research, Flinders Medical Centre, various University departments and CSIRO divisions, and the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories. Firms and other organisations include Biotechnology Australia Pty Ltd, Biotechnology Research Enterprises SA Pty Ltd, F H Faulding & Co. Ltd, Gradient Laboratories, Disposable Products Pty Ltd, and the Sydney Blood Bank. The projects relate to veterinary and anti-malarial vaccines, plant virus detection, insecticides, laboratory equipment and diagnostic techniques based on monoclonal antibodies.

Funds allocated under the Program in 1983-84 also include $2.5 million to extend the Australian Industrial Research and Development Incentives Scheme to encompass biotechnology projects. Apart from the Program, $7.8 million went to CSIRO for biotechnology research, and $400,000 to the Howard Florey Institute at Melbourne University.

Other important Government actions include steps to improve the flow of venture capital to growth industries from the Australian Industrial Development Corporation, and taxation incentives to encourage investment in specially established venture capital companies called Managment Investment Companies.
Commercial and economic usefulness of patents

Against this background of support, the role which patents might play as a stimulus to development may not be a major one. But the role is essential. Commercial exploitation is not possible without some form of protection in an area where huge amounts of money are needed. Patent protection is particularly important in assisting penetration by Australians into foreign markets. It would be tragic if Australia had to buy back products from overseas which were developed here or if we could only manufacture them here under licence.
In 1980 the United States Supreme Court in the Chakrabarty case ruled for the first time that living micro-organisms were patentable. That was regarded as a landmark decision for American industry.

In Australia, however, the Patent Office has long regarded biological processes and micro-organisms themselves as patentable, provided they satisfy the usual pre-conditions for obtaining a patent. That is, they must be novel and non- obvious, industrially useful, and fully described in the patent specification. This information has been widely disseminated-see, for example, a paper given in November 1981 by Philip Thomas of the Patent Office at a Sydney symposium on ' Genetic Engineering-Commercial Opportunities in Australia'.

In October 1983 the Patent Office published a survey entitled 'Genetic Engineering-Patent Trends and Developments'. Based on that survey and later figures provided by the Office, the number of genetic engineering inventions for which patents were sought world-wide increased from 74 in 1981 to 109 in 1982 and 212 in 1983. They are currently running at about 7 new inventions per week. Corresponding figures for patent applications lodged in Australia were 44 in 1981, 49 in 1982 and 67 in 1983. In 1979 there were only 5.

Biotechnology is, of course, broader than genetic engineering. But those figures give an indication of the rate of growth, not of basic research, but of potential commercial applications of biotechnology. Yet, of 187 applications lodged in Australia in the years 1979-1983, only 1 was of Australian origin. Australians do perform research, but what do they do with it?

We used to be satisfied with the high-flown notion that research findings do the greatest public good if they are given to the world. The difficulty is that the rest of the world is more entrepreneurial and less altruistic than that, with the result that Australia is falling behind. The patent system recognises both the desirability of publication and the commercial realities for the innovator. There is a common misconception that patents require secrecy. In fact , provided a patent application is lodged first, a researcher can publish the invention without jeopardising the application (although if it is too early, this may give away some of the lead held over industry competitors). The patent application will be published in any event, usually 18 months after lodgement.

The purpose of patents is to promote economic development. The mechanism is by way of proprietary rights in the form of a limited term monopoly for new inventions. Their economic operation stems first from protection which gives an incentive to invent and innovate, and second from the disclosure of information which is required from the patentee in exchange for patent rights. For an Australian company, proprietary rights protect its local and foreign interests in research and development, and improve its competitive position in other countries. the availability of protection provides incentive for investment. Disclosure enables Australians to have access to information about the leading edge of technology owned by foreign patentees. Over 90% of patents granted in Australia are of foreign origin.

I am aware that the patent system has not been without its critics. I hope the current review by the Australian Property Advisory Committee will yield constructive suggestions on how it can be made to operate more effectively in advancing Australia's technological development.
Patents Amendment Bill

In the area of biotechnology, however, it is already apparent that patent law is failing to meet the needs of patentees, industry and the public. It is not uncommon for the law to lag behind social and technological change (if the two can indeed be separated). It is up to Government to make sure it catches up. In the case of biotechnology patents the lag has arisen from the virtual impossibility of carrying out an invention without access to a sample of the micro-organism used.

Existing law requires a full written description of the invention. But where the invention involves the use of a micro-organism strain which is not available to researchers, a written description may well be next to useless. An antibiotic producing strain might have been isolated by unrepeatable fluke from the bottom of a lake in Scandinavia or from the soil in someone's backyard. The most thorough characterisation of the strain will not help anyone (apart from the patentee) to test the truthfulness of the patent specifications or to make further developments on the basis of the invention. The information is only good if you can obtain the actual materials needed as a starting point for further work. What is needed is a sample of the organism.

Ultimately a micro-organism could be defined genetically in terms of the nucleotide base sequence of its DNA. In standard code the four bases are represented by the letters C, G, A and T. The first chromosome completely mapped out for any organism reads: CCGTC- AGGATTGACACCCTCCCAATTGTATGTTTTCA- TGCCTCCAAATCTTGGAGGAGGCTTTTTTAT- GGTTCGTTCTTACCTCTCTGAATGTCAC . . . and so on for a total of 5,375 bases. That was for a bacteriophage (a type of virus which destroys bacteria) known as OX174. The full sequence may be perused by anyone who is interested but not keen to consult scientific literature in Douglas R. Hofstadter's book, 'Godel, Escher, Bach: an Eternal Golden Braid'.
Far more fascinating reading could be had for E. coli DNA, which contains 4.5 million bases. The sequence would occupy about 1,000 pages of Hansard, if Standing Orders would permit me to read it.

Even then the information contained in the base sequence would need to be interpreted into useful form, and the most skilled biochemist would be unable or certainly unwillng to attempt to re-create the organism. For practical commercial purposes all this information would be less useful than a single cell of the bacterium. In a standard culture medium, one cell would divide into two identical offspring in about 30 minutes. Commercial quantities of the organism would take only days to produce.

The essence of this Bill is to complement the existing requirement of a full description by also requiring deposit, with a prescribed depositary institution, of patent strains of micro-organisms which are not reasonably available. That new principle is to be fond in sub-sections 40 (3) and (5) of the Patents Act which are added by the Bill.

As a result of the amendments, Australian industry will be guaranteed access to strains of all micro-organisms used in patented processes, just as access to information in written descriptions of inventions is guaranteed under the current law.

In practice, depositary institutions hold a number of samples of each deposited strain. Most bacteria and fungi can be stored in freeze-dried form in small vials or frozen in liquid nitrogen in plastic ampoules or straws. Priceless samples can be readily reconstituted and turned to commercial purposes, provided that no patent is infringed.

There are some cases where the specification itself describes how to make or obtain the new strain. If a person skilled in the art could reasonably be expected to be able to perform the invention without first having a sample of the micro-organism, then the requirement to make a deposit will not apply.

A corollary to the deposit requirement is that if a deposit is required, then compliance with sub-section 40 (5) will satisfy the requirement of a full description of the micro-organism. That will also apply where the invention is itself a new micro-organism, relieving the applicant of the need to provide an excessively detailed description when a deposit, supplemented by relevant information on the organism's characteristics, is a realistic alternative.

Mere deposit without some guarantee of access would not be enough. The applicant therefore must also give authority for the furnishing of samples of the micro-organism in accordance with the regulations and the Budapest Treaty. The terms of the authority to be required by the regulations will be discussed with industry to ensure that a fair balance of interest is struck. It is fundamental to the notion of patents that the patentee should be left with an enforceable monopoly. An unauthorised user of a strain can still be sued for infringement.

The second aspect of the Bill is to implement the Budapest Treaty. That will ensure that the benefits provided by the deposit requirements will be available to Australians who patent abroad and to Australians seeking access to strains deposited by foreign patentees. The main idea of the Treaty is to enable a single deposit in any International Depositary Authority recognised by the Treaty to suffice for the puposes of the patent law of all member countries. To date 12 countries are members, including the US, the UK and other major European countries, and Japan. Australia intends to accede to the Treaty when the Bill comes into force.

The Bill recognises all International Depositary Authorities for the purpose of satisfying Australian deposit requirements. There are currenty 9 Authorities. The Minister for Science and Technology has visited one of them-the Fermentation Research Institute in Tsukuba, Japan-a very impressive institution offering a range of services to industry and research.

The remainder of the Bill supports these essential features. For example, provisions are made to remedy an inability of a depositary institution to supply samples, and to require a late deposit where a micro-organism ceases to be reasonably available.

To gain the full benefits of participation of the new provisions, we intend to establish an Australian International Depositary Authority which will be recognised under the Budapest Treaty. Australians wishing to patent abroad in order to protect exports will then be able to satisfy the deposit requirements of foreign laws in many instances with a single deposit made locally.
Financial impact

The direct financial implications of the Bill are minimal. No additional resources would be required by the Patent Office in dealing with patent applications where a deposit had been made, and no direct contributions would be involved in acceding to the Treaty.

Establishment of an International Depositary Authority within an existing Government institution is not expected to exceed $10,000. Ongoing costs of an Authority should be recovered from fees levied on depositors. Fees charged by overseas Authorities range from $300 to $1,000 for storage of deposits for the 30 year period required by the Treaty.

The indirect implications for industry are very substantial. While the fees charged for lodging deposits are sizeable, there will be a reduced need for expensive drafting of patent specifications. But far more important are the advantages from having access to deposited strains. Although the value of access will vary from case to case, it is potentially enormous.
Conclusion

Developments projects based on Australian research are now causing great interest internationally. This was brought home to the Minister for Science and Technology recently when he visited two US companies which are world leaders in biotechnology-Genentech in San Francisco and Agrigenetics in Boulder, Colorado. We must stay in the race and keep ahead in areas where we have the lead. This needs a vigorous approach from industry, research bodies and Government.

The Patents Amendment Bill demonstrates the Government's awareness of the need for commercial realisation of Australia's research and development efforts in biotechnology. Industry and researchers must continue to convert opportunities into advantages in this competitive field. The Bill offers improved ways in which that can be achieved.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Peter Rae) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON REGULATIONS AND ORDINANCES

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to contingent notice of motion given by me I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That so much of the Standing Orders be suspended as would prevent the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate moving a motion relating to the order of business on the Notice Paper.
I speak to the motion so that the Senate is aware of what I am seeking. I will be seeking leave to move a motion in these terms:
That intervening General Business be postponed until after the consideration of General Business Notice of Motion No. 78 for the reference of a matter to the Regulations and Ordinances Committee.

The Senate will be aware of, because it has before it on the Notice Paper, a notice of motion by Senator Durack which he gave yesterday and which is No. 78 on the Notice Paper for today as shown on page 3812. That notice of motion is to refer certain regulations to the Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances. I will not in the course of these remarks specify them but they relate to the disallowance motion which was moved, I think by Senator Mason, and which has had extensive debate in this place. In the broad, the regulations relate to the classification of publications and the very vexed question of, I suppose, censorship, to put it shortly. What the motion, notice of which has been given by Senator Durack, seeks is to have the various regulations which have been the subject of so much debate-I point out that the debate has yet to be concluded but it will have to be concluded when we return after the couple of weeks up-put to the Committee to examine whether the regulations and ordinance referred to:
(a) restrict unduly the Commonwealth's existing powers to prevent the importation of publications, including videotapes-
(i) promoting or encouraging violence,
(ii) promoting or encouraging the use of hard drugs, and
(iii) depicting hard-core pornography, sexual violence or other gross obscenities;

The proposal also asks the Committee to examine whether those regulations and ordinance restrict unduly the Commonwealth's existing powers to require videos not imported for public exhibition to be registered by the Film Censorship Board before release by Customs. The third point the Committee is asked to examine is whether those regulations and ordinance restrict unduly the power of the Commonwealth to protect children from exposure to publications previously referred to.

I do not think there is any doubt from the level of interest that there has been in the debate on this disallowance that this is a matter of very broad public interest. Over the last 24 hours I have had the chance to read some of the material which has recently come from an inquiry sponsored by the House of Lords on this subject and I can say only that I think there are genuine difficulties facing us in this area. I can see that the Attorney-General ( Senator Gareth Evans) is getting very impatient. I am trying to restrict myself to explaining why I am seeking the suspension of Standing Orders and why I would like this matter to be dealt with today.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Leader of the Opposition will understand that we do not want a duplication of the debate.

—I understand that and I will try to be succinct. The simple point I am trying to make is that this is a matter of wide public interest and proper public and Senate concern. What we are seeking is that this motion, of which notice was given yesterday, should have an opportunity of being considered by the Senate--
—Last night.

—Notice was given last night. We should have an opportunity of having it considered by the Senate today. The reason for that is that we will be returning to this debate when the sittings resume in a couple of weeks time and it is the desire of the Opposition to have an opportunity for that Committee consideration during the two weeks while the Parliament is not sitting. We believe that the Senate would be aided in its consideration of this important matter if it had a report from the Committee. If this matter is dealt with by simply postponing it to the next fortnight's sittings we will lose that possible advantage. The question must be decided today whether we are to have the opportunity of a relevant Committee examination. I have had a preliminary indication from the Australian Democrats that they are not inclined to support this motion. Having had that indication, I simply direct some comments to that point.
—Are you speaking about the motion to suspend the Standing Orders?

—Yes, Mr President. I hope that this will not need lengthy consideration. All that the Opposition is seeking is a committee examination of the questions I have mentioned. It does not seek a determination of this vexed and difficult issue. It does not seek to reopen the issues which have had extensive debate. It seeks the advantage of some committee consideration. I stress that that advantage can be obtained today. It cannot be obtained in a fortnight or three weeks' time. I specifically ask the Democrats to consider the general principle that the Senate's detailed consideration of this matter will be assisted by some committee consideration. I ask them to put aside any other concerns they might have and to give their support for the motion to suspend Standing Orders.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is probably a well meaning attempt by the Opposition to bring its point of view, or perhaps a public point of view, to a matter which, as the Leader of the Opposition, Senator Chaney, has said, has had a great deal of debate already. It is still in the transitional stage in the sense that I have moved a motion for disallowance of ordinances, which has been adjourned, and there have been various other motions, including one from Senator Harradine, to resolve this very complex matter. It is a complex matter. It is one of great difficulty which requires a good deal of thought and input from the community. We are getting that kind of input now. We would oppose immediately the suspension of Standing Orders, although we might be inclined, perhaps, to look at this later in the day. There may be an opportunity then to look at the motion, if it could be adjourned for that amount of time. I have not had time yet to consult the Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances, and the Committee's Chairman, Senator Coates, is not in the chamber. I do not know what his view is. It would be a grave lack of courtesy on the part of the Senate to visit a busy committee with a reference such as this, which must be an urgent one. As Senator Chaney has said, it will have to be looked at during the next two weeks.

SPEECH.PARA: The other point is that it is not an easy matter. There is no way the Australian Democrats could agree with Senator Chaney that what is required of the Committee is something that it could knock off in an afternoon. What is required is a matter which could result in weeks of work. The Committee could receive responses from the public-as we know, many members of the public have strong views on this subject-which might occupy it for months. I am speaking to the question of suspension of Standing Orders because I think whether or not we have been able to consult the Committee bears directly, I suggest, on the question of suspension.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Committee been consulted?
—Yes. The Chairman has rejected it.
—That is the point. The Attorney-General says that the Chairman of the Committee, Senator Coates, has been consulted and that he has rejected the idea.

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It is becoming difficult from the Chair's point of view, to hear Senator Mason. I ask Senator Mason and those senators who are interjecting to restrict their remarks to the reason for the suspension.

—I suggest to you, Mr President, with regard to the suspension, that it is to the point that the Attorney-General has interjected that the Chairman of the Committee has been consulted and that he has rejected the idea.
—What right has he to reject it?
—What right has he to say that?

—Senator Harradine and members of the Opposition say: 'What right has he to say that'. I think it is a good idea for those remarks to be placed on the record. If honourable senators do not have sufficient respect for the Chairman of the Committee to place a reasonable workload on the Committee, we will create a precedent in this place.

—Mr President, I take a point of order. Under the Standing Orders of the Senate the references taken by committees is a matter for decision by the Senate. I remind the Senate that Senator Tate voted against the reference to the Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs of the National Crimes Authority Bill. There are ample precedents for Caucus members of the Australian Labor Party to do their party's bidding on these matters. It is not a matter which under the Standing Orders lies within the province of the Chairman of a committee. It is a matter which lies within the province of the Senate.

—The matter that is before the Chair now is the simple question of the suspension of Standing Orders to enable Senator Chaney to move a motion. The Senate now has to determine whether there will be a suspension of Standing Orders in the first instance. If it so agrees, Senator Chaney will be allowed to move a motion. That motion can then be debated. At this stage, I ask all honourable senators simply to keep to the question of the suspension of Standing Orders.

—Thank you for that ruling, Mr President. The points you have made bear directly on the comments I will now make. Of course, they relate to the comments that Senator Chaney has made. Certainly, it is the Senate's authority and right to refer matters to committees. But surely there is an obligation on all honourable senators in this place to accommodate those committees as reasonably as we can and not to make unreasonable demands on them. I suggest to you, Mr President, that that bears directly on whether or not we agree to the suspension of Standing Orders at this stage and allow this matter to come on at this point. I make the point again that this matter has been dropped on the Senate at short notice. I cannot see why it could not have been done earlier yesterday--
—Would it have made any difference?

—That is a matter I do not think we have to debate. Senator Archer can study his own conscience on that one. It does not matter whether it would have made any difference or not. The facts are that that did not happen. That is what we have to examine. If we get to the stage here where we study airy-fairy suggestions such as Senator Archer has made, we will never get any work done. I wonder whether the Leader of the Opposition, if he feels strongly on this matter , might agree to adjourn this matter until later in the day. That would at least give everybody time to look at the motion to suspend Standing Orders. Then we could perhaps decide what we were going to do. If we cannot do that, I do not see how the Democrats can in conscience support it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GRIMES
TALKER.ROLE: Acting Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: — At the moment the Government is not inclined to support this motion. However, we are willing to consider the proposition. In light of the sort of indignation we have heard here this morning from the Leader of the Opposition, Senator Chaney, I would like to point out the simple facts of this matter. Very late yesterday afternoon, Senator Durack came to me, as the Minister on duty, and said that he wanted to seek leave to move a notice of motion, something that he could have done yesterday morning, the morning before that or the morning before that. The notice of motion was obviously hurriedly drawn up some time yesterday. I had no objection-as I do not think I ever have any objection-to people doing that. I have done it in the past. Of course, no indication was given to me that we were going to add to the large number of items on the Notice Paper-for example, Senator Mason's notice of motion, which has been debated, and Senator Harradine' s notice of motion, which has been debated and will be debated again today-and that what the Leader of the Opposition was going to do, apparently without the agreement of the other Opposition parties, was to interfere with General Business. I notice that the first two General Business items on the agenda this afternoon-if I am right-are, in fact, matters that the Australian Democrats have raised. I do not think this is a satisfactory way to go on.

SPEECH.PARA: As for the highly indignant statements to the effect that it is up to the Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances to take any reference that the Senate gives to it, of course that is true. Any reference that this Senate decides to pass to a committee should be passed to a committee. But as long as I have been in this place, it has been common courtesy to consult the chairman of that committee, first of all, to see whether the committee has the time to do the work and secondly, to see what sort of timetable it has. Quite frankly, considering the references on the agenda for that committee, that committee would be very hard pressed to complete that reference in three, four or five weeks, let alone two weeks.

TALK.START.PARA: —There was no such approach.

—No such approach was made. Let us not get indignant about the rights of honourable senators and the rights of the Senate. I agree with all of those rights. But let us remember that there is a bit of common courtesy in this place and that, in circumstances such as these, the chairmen of committees have always been approached. We received this notice of motion late yesterday afternoon. We received it because members of the Australian Democrats and members of the Government did not object to Senator Durack's seeking leave. So we got it at very short notice and very late. This morning we find, after going through the normal procedures, that what the Opposition wants to do is to suspend Standing Orders in order to bring this matter on under General Business, when General Business consists of items that the Australian Democrats have under General Business by arrangement with the Liberal Party of Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: We are doing this in a situation in which we already have two items on the Notice Paper dealing with this matter. I do not know whether the Opposition is just indulging in political tactics-I have no objection to that-to keep debates going, to extend debates and to extend the number of debates. I do not know whether the Opposition is confused and has not been able to work out what its tactics should be. But it is not a very satisfactory circumstance. The Government is certainly not willing, without fair consideration, to go along with the suspension of Standing Orders to alter the General Business paper this afternoon without some concern that the people who already have that General Business time are in some agreement with it. If it is desired to adjourn the suspension of Standing Orders debate until later, if that is what the Democrats are requesting, to consider the matter--

TALK.START.PARA: —We will agree to the suspension now and to debate it later.
—All right; we will go along with that. But I think that all honourable senators on the other side must make up their minds as to what they want to do.
—I should like to point out that the motion moved by the Leader of the Opposition is merely a suspension motion to enable the Leader of the Opposition to move a rearrangement motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a very brief statement, Mr President, so that what I am going to do will be made quite clear to the Senate and there is no misunderstanding.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand now that on the basis that if I move my motion and then adjourn debate on it to a later hour this day, there is a preparedness on the part of the Government and the Australian Democrats to agree to Standing Orders being suspended to allow the moving--
—Do you mean that you would adjourn the rearrangement motion?
—Yes. So I shall seek the carriage of the motion to suspend Standing Orders, move the motion that I indicated I would move, and then seek to adjourn debate on it until a later hour this day.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GRIMES
TALKER.ROLE: Acting Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave -I would assume from both the Australian Democrats and the Liberals that the resumption of that debate will be in General Business time.
—Yes, and we shall have to talk about that.
—The Opposition will be using up its own time, not ours.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-It is a reasonable and sensible course of action that the Senate has taken. I learnt about this matter this morning. The notice was given, apparently, at about 6 o' clock last night. We shall certainly agree to Senator Chaney's first motion now with a view to debating the other issue later in the day. But we would hope, if we could reach a gentleperson's agreement, that the Liberal Party of Australia will not eat into the time of General Business, because we have been waiting patiently for weeks, in agreement with the Liberals, to have two important issues of our own debated during that time. We hope that the Liberals will do the right thing and not encroach into our time during the General Business debate.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That intervening General Business be postponed until after the consideration of General Business Notice of Motion No. 78 for the reference of a matter to the Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances.
I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: CUSTOMS (CINEMATOGRAPH FILMS) REGULATIONSCLASSIFICATION OF PUBLICATIONS REGULATIONS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave, Mr President, to make a statement, because I am not too sure where we have reached at present.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Am I correct in the understanding that Senator Chaney's motion will be the subject of debate this afternoon?
—Yes.
—If that is so, then the matters about which I am moving disallowance will be matters either to be referred or not to be referred to a committee, as the case may be.
—That is correct.
—In that event I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That Business of the Senate, Notices of Motion Nos 1 and 2, standing in the name of Senator Harradine and relating to the disallowance of regulations be postponed until the next day of sitting.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
